awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Improving fleet operational metrics through service optimization with automated learning of vehicle energy performance models for zero-emission public transport
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase (SBIR) II project will research and validate an internet-of-things (IOT) platform to help commercial fleets transition to zero-emission vehicles (ZEVs). The ZEV transition is the primary solution to the decarbonization of the transportation sector, which is the largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the US. The project focuses on transit agencies, with the ultimate goal of lowering both operating costs and capital costs of their ZEV fleets. Coupled with the current funding support by federal, state and local governments to transit agencies to purchase ZEVs, this project could accelerate the decarbonization of the US transit fleet. A 50% transition of the US transit fleet to ZEVs will reduce nearly 200 million metric tons of carbom dioxide (CO2) equivalent, providing cleaner air quality and reducing urban noise pollution, particularly in low-income communities that rely more heavily on transit services for their transportation needs. The addressable market of Transportation Management Systems will grow from $8.8 billion in 2020 to $27.48 billion in 2028. Demonstrating success in the transit segment will enable the replication of this approach to other fleet segments like school bus fleets, last-mile and mid-mile delivery fleets, and long-haul trucking fleets. 

The intellectual merit of this project is the design and implementation of an artificial intelligence software platform to automatically learn predictive vehicle models of transit ZEVs and provide recommendation services to transit agencies. The Phase II project has three integrated goals.  The first goal is the development of energy prediction algorithms which are scalable and highly accurate. Transit ZEV fleets have stochastic load changes, high sensitivity to operator driving style and high variation of battery size, weight and driving range, even for similar vehicles. These challenges will be addressed by developing automated learning techniques built on algorithms developed in Phase I, which use contextualized data from ZEV stops and trips. The second goal is to validate the prediction accuracy via pilots with ZEV fleets providing scheduled bus services.  The final goal is development of real-time, scalable, fleet optimization algorithms which optimize daily assignment and charge management of ZEV fleets. Chance-constrained optimization will be merged with predictive control theory to address scalability and real-time performance of the resulting optimization algorithms. These recommendations will, if successful, demonstrate highly accurate predictions of charge usage, a substantial increase in ZEV fleet utilization, and a reduction of transit ZEV fleet operating costs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the Phase II project, we researched, developed and validated methods and associated algorithms which automatically learn predictive vehicle models of Battery Electric Buses (BEBs) and provide two core optimization services to transit agencies: optimization of daily assignment of BEBs to drivers and blocks in order to maximize fleet utilization and optimization of charge management to lower energy costs. These optimization services are branded as EV Fleet Realtime Guidance™. We deployed the systems to more than 10 transit operator sites and demonstrated (i) significant improvement in their BEBs fleet utilization; (ii) significant reduction in the operating costs of their BEB fleet including energy costs; and (iii) improvement in customer and driver satisfaction.  This project compared the energy predictions of this novel IoT platform to actual, real-world driving, and demonstrated (A) accurate predictions of charge usage to perform work and time to charge as well as (B) up to a 27% increase in BEB fleet utilization on a per bus basis.
Intellectual Merit
The R&D plan incorporated three integrated goals: (G1) Developing algorithms which are scalable, highly accurate, and tailored to BEB fleets. Compared to passenger battery electric vehicles, transit BEBs fleets have stochastic load changes, high sensitivity to operator driving style and high variation between battery size, weight and driving range within vehicles of the same make and model. We addressed these challenges by developing automated learning techniques built on Phase I algorithms which use contextualized data from BEB stops and trips. (G2) Validated prediction accuracy vs actual on the BEB fleet of transit agencies with scheduled bus services. (G3) Developed real-time scalable fleet optimization algorithms which use the high-precision predictions of the AI Cloud platform to provide two services to transit agencies: (A) optimize daily assignment of BEBs to drivers and blocks in order to maximize fleet utilization and (B) optimize charge management of the BEB fleet in order to maximize fleet utilization and minimize charging costs. Chance-Constrained optimization was merged with predictive control theory to address scalability and real-time performance of the resulting optimization algorithms.
Each of these goals was demonstrated at a variety of pilots and full implementations at transit depots.
Broader/Commercial Impact
Transit Fleet Electrification Initiatives have kicked off around the world to provide lower impact and more cost-effective transportation. EV Fleet Realtime GuidanceTM enables transit agencies to lower the operating costs of their BEB fleet and make it competitive with their fossil-fuel fleet providing a sound economic basis to transition their fleets to BEBs. This coupled with funding support by federal, state and local governments to transit agencies to purchase BEBs, can support a diverse and sustainable transit fleet mix. The demonstrated success in the transit segment enables AV-Connect (WideSense) to offer other fleet segments like school bus fleets, last-mile & mid-mile delivery fleets and service fleets similar value to urban transit BEB fleet operations financial and operational benefits to accelerate their transition to BEVs.
